collection_readme.name: README.md
collection_readme.html:
IBM QRadar Ansible Collection

Tech Preview

This is the Ansible Collection provided by the Ansible Security Automation Team for automating actions in IBM QRadar SIEM.

This Collection is meant for distribution via Ansible Galaxy as is available for all Ansible users to utilize, contribute to, and provide feedback about.

Using IBM QRadar Ansible Collection

An example for using this collection to manage a log source with IBM QRadar is as follows.

inventory.ini (Note the password should be managed by a Vault for a production environment.

[qradar]
qradar.example.com

[qradar:vars]
ansible_network_os=ibm.qradar.qradar
ansible_user=admin
ansible_httpapi_pass=SuperSekretPassword
ansible_httpapi_use_ssl=yes
ansible_httpapi_validate_certs=yes
ansible_connection=httpapi

Using the modules with Fully Qualified Collection Name (FQCN)

With Ansible Collections there are various ways to utilize them either by calling specific Content from the Collection, such as a module, by it's Fully Qualified Collection Name (FQCN) as we'll show in this example or by defining a Collection Search Path as the examples below will display.

qradar_with_collections_example.yml

---
- name: Testing URI manipulation of QRadar with FQCN
  hosts: qradar
  gather_facts: false
  tasks:
    - name: create log source
      ibm.qradar.qradar_log_source_management:
        name: "Ansible Collections Example Log Source"
        type_name: "Linux OS"
        state: present
        description: "Ansible Collections Example Log Source Description"

Define your collection search path at the Play level

Below we specify our collection at the Play level which allows us to use the qradar_log_source_management module without the need for the FQCN for each task.

qradar_with_collections_example.yml

---
- name: Testing URI manipulation of QRadar
  hosts: qradar
  gather_facts: false
  collections:
    - ibm.qradar
  tasks:
    - name: create log source
      qradar_log_source_management:
        name: "Ansible Collections Example Log Source"
        type_name: "Linux OS"
        state: present
        description: "Ansible Collections Example Log Source Description"

Define your collection search path at the Block level

Another option for Collection use is below. Here we use the block level keyword instead of Play level as with the previous example. In this scenario we are able to use the qradar_log_source_management module without the need for the FQCN for each task but with an optionally more specific scope of Collection Search Path than specifying at the Play level.

qradar_with_collections_block_example.yml

---
- name: Testing URI manipulation of QRadar
  hosts: qradar
  gather_facts: false
  tasks:
    - name: collection namespace block
      block:
        - name: create log source
          qradar_log_source_management:
            name: "Ansible Collections Example Log Source"
            type_name: "Linux OS"
            state: present
            description: "Ansible Collections Example Log Source Description"
      collections:
        - ibm.qradar

Directory Structure

  • docs/: local documentation for the collection
  • license.txt: optional copy of license(s) for this collection
  • galaxy.yml: source data for the MANIFEST.json that will be part of the collection package
  • playbooks/: playbooks reside here
  • tasks/: this holds 'task list files' for include_tasks/import_tasks usage
  • plugins/: all ansible plugins and modules go here, each in its own subdir
  • modules/: ansible modules
  • lookups/: lookup plugins
  • filters/: Jinja2 filter plugins
  • ... rest of plugins
  • README.md: information file (this file)
  • roles/: directory for ansible roles
  • tests/: tests for the collection's content

doc.author: Ansible Security Automation Team (@maxamillion) <https://github.com/ansible-security>"
description: This module obtains information about one or many QRadar Rules, with filter options
notes: You may provide many filters and they will all be applied, except for C(id) as that will return only the Rule identified by the unique ID provided.

options.name: id
description: Obtain only information of the Rule with provided ID

options.name: name
description: Obtain only information of the Rule that matches the provided name

options.name: origin
description: Obtain only information of Rules that are of a certain origin

options.name: owner
description: Obtain only information of Rules owned by a certain user

options.name: type
description: Obtain only information for the Rules of a certain type

doc.short_description: Obtain information about one or many QRadar Rules, with filter options

doc.author: Ansible Security Automation Team (@maxamillion) <https://github.com/ansible-security>
description: Manage state of QRadar Rules, with filter options

options.name: id
description: Manage state of a QRadar Rule by ID

options.name: name
description: Manage state of a QRadar Rule by name

options.name: owner
description: Manage ownership of a QRadar Rule

options.name: state
description: Manage state of a QRadar Rule

doc.short_description: Manage state of QRadar Rules, with filter options

doc.author: Ansible Security Automation Team (@maxamillion) <https://github.com/ansible-security>
description: This module allows to create a QRadar Offense note

options.name: id
description: Offense ID to operate on

doc.short_description: Create or update a QRadar Offense Note

doc.author: Ansible Security Automation Team (@maxamillion) <https://github.com/ansible-security>
description: This module allows to obtain information about one or many QRadar Offenses, with filter options
notes: You may provide many filters and they will all be applied, except for C(id) as that will return only

options.name: assigned_to
description: Obtain only information of Offenses assigned to a certain user

options.name: closing_reason
description: Obtain only information of Offenses that were closed by a specific closing reason

options.name: closing_reason_id
description: Obtain only information of Offenses that were closed by a specific closing reason ID

options.name: follow_up
description: Obtain only information of Offenses that are marked with the follow up flag

options.name: id
description: Obtain only information of the Offense with provided ID

options.name: name
description: Obtain only information of the Offense that matches the provided name

options.name: protected
description: Obtain only information of Offenses that are protected

options.name: status
description: Obtain only information of Offenses of a certain status

doc.short_description: Obtain information about one or many QRadar Offenses, with filter options

contains.name: qradar_offenses
source
contains.description: Init system of the service. One of C(systemd), C(sysv), C(upstart).

contains.name: state
contains.description: State of the service. Either C(running), C(stopped), or C(unknown).

contains.name: status
contains.description: State of the service. Either C(enabled), C(disabled), or C(unknown).
contains.returned: systemd systems or RedHat/SUSE flavored sysvinit/upstart

contains.description: IBM QRadar Offenses found based on provided filters

doc.author: Ansible Security Automation Team (@maxamillion) <https://github.com/ansible-security>
description: This module allows to assign, protect, follow up, set status, and assign closing reason to QRadar Offenses
notes: Requires one of C(name) or C(id) be provided
Only one of C(closing_reason) or C(closing_reason_id) can be provided

options.name: assigned_to
description: Assign to an user, the QRadar username should be provided

options.name: closing_reason
description: Assign a predefined closing reason here, by name.

options.name: closing_reason_id
description: Assign a predefined closing reason here, by id.

options.name: follow_up
description: Set or unset the flag to follow up on a QRadar Offense

options.name: id
description: ID of Offense

options.name: protected
description: Set or unset the flag to protect a QRadar Offense

options.name: status
description: One of "open", "hidden" or "closed". (Either all lower case or all caps)

doc.short_description: Take action on a QRadar Offense

doc.author: Ansible Security Automation Team (@maxamillion) <https://github.com/ansible-security>
description: This module allows for addition, deletion, or modification of Log Sources in QRadar
notes: Either C(type) or C(type_id) is required

options.name: description
description: Description of log source

options.name: identifier
description: Log Source Identifier (Typically IP Address or Hostname of log source)

options.name: name
description: Name of Log Source

options.name: protocol_type_id
description: Type of protocol by id, as defined in QRadar Log Source Types Documentation

options.name: state
description: Add or remove a log source.

options.name: type_id
description: Type of resource by id, as defined in QRadar Log Source Types Documentation

options.name: type_name
description: Type of resource by name

doc.author: Ansible Security Automation Team (@maxamillion) <https://github.com/ansible-security>
description: This module allows for INCREMENTAL or FULL deployments
notes: This module does not support check mode because the QRadar REST API does not offer stateful inspection of configuration deployments

options.name: type
description: Type of deployment

doc.author: Ansible Security Automation Team
description: This HttpApi plugin provides methods to connect to IBM QRadar over a HTTP(S)-based api.
